channel.title: The protests in Libya
channel.description:
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12604760
Gaddafi, today, denied that any protests in the Libyan capital ever happened.
This guy should be removed. It's clear that rapid change is happening across North Africa and the Middle East and to me he seems like a power hungry dictator is trying to prove to the world that he is still in charge.
I'm completely for the revolutions that are happening, and I just wish that these ignorant leaders would listen to the people that kept them in control of their regimes.

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @Echo3 Echo_
item.description:
@Echo3 wrote:

I laughed at the part when he said that the people of Libya love him.

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Special forces around the world are pretty much equal, except for their numbers. Maybe some are more specialized in certain territories, but I know that most train in pretty much every territory (arctic, desert, etc…)

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

As great as the UK/Australian SAS, American Navy SEALS, etc etc are… what makes you think they can parachute into the middle of Libya and take down a dictator whose regime was oppressive and military based?

You talk like you think he’s in a house and they’ll knock on the door at 4am and take him out. This guy is going to be guarded, Gaddafi’s led a dictatorship for a long fucking time, something tells me his personal security is probably quite fucking impressive. Not saying it’s impossible, just saying a stealth assassination by any special services would be dificult and prone to publication (the country is of course full of journalists).

[quote=“Radeon, post:35, topic:384488”]Well special forces aren’t exactly what they’re cut out to be. Rebels ‘hold British SAS’ in Libya after bungled diplomatic mission

And aren’t Australian SAS inferior to the British SAS? I don’t think the navy seals are much better than either of them.[/quote]

Special forces get caught all the time without public knowledge, they’re also out on operations that we’ll never know about. They also die all the time because half the missions they go on are suicidal. Special forces soldiers are fucking awesome but they’re going up against incredible odds. Bravo two zero in an OKish BBC film that tries to demonstrate a mission going wrong but there are far better documentaries with real accounts from these kinds of soldiers (although they’ll never give specific details, they will literally just tell you they’ve been caught and how they were tortured never where, when or why.) You could torture one of these guys for months and they’d never tell you a thing.

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

I don’t think there is any real measurement of how good different special forces regiments are. All those mentioned would probably be good enough to get the job done.

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:31, topic:384488”][quote author=Niall link=topic=480254.msg3518427#msg3518427 date=1299199414]
more like, the mercenaries gaddafi paid are probably under an agreement that if he is assassinated they would slaughter the people… hell, even if they aren’t I doubt they would leave without taking everything of value, or that no one would care if they just up and go
[/quote]

Mercenaries by definition are in it for the money, nothing else. If the person paying them died they would just leave, not slaughter people.[/quote]

I realize this but given the context I doubt they will just pack up and leave, they’re enforcing the power after all, they can take what they want

my argument is flawed anyway but it’s all just entertaining a hypothetical situation

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I’m leaning towards the US shooting down the Libyan planes, to be honest. There are a lot of Libyans asking the US to do that, so that they can take care of the rest.

Assassinating Khadaffi is stupid. He should be tried by his own people, and rot in jail.

There are 3 Dutch marines stuck in Libya, they tried to do the same as the British did and rescue 2 people with a helicopter. They failed miserably. LOOOOOOOOL

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Sending missiles means official involvement. Knocking down doors in the night and offing a guy provides the chance for plausible deniability. The world can speculate all they like, but it’d be a tough call for anyone to definitively point their finger at the US and scream ‘you did it!!1’.

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:18, topic:384488”]I see nothing wrong with a no-fly zone. The other alternative is to drop a SEAL team in there under the cover of darkness, and they can then move to off the guy directly.
I’m guessing nobody would support that, though… but it’d be effective and quick.[/quote]

Spec-ops would be cool but very unnecessary. I’m sure the US military can land a tomahawk missile between his two testicles if need be. Taking him and his sons out might just stop the violence.

The problem with this though is that after the Afghan and Iraq war, US efforts to assist in regime change will almost certainly have the people thinking they are trying to force their own ideals over Libya.

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Mopman:

You seem to imply that “taking him out”, even if it wasn’t ridiculous, wouldn’t cause death in the streets.

Wouldn’t be the first assassination that was greenlit by a government, so I don’t see why it’s ridiculous.
I was getting at the fact that if he wasn’t in power then nobody would be paying mercenaries to kill civilians.

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Lothy:

Australia could send in a team that is just as capable as the Navy SEALs – we have an SAS regiment

In this situation I think SAS would kick more ass unless Gaddafi is on a boat somewhere lol. Delta + SAS should go in there and take care of the mercenaries and let the people have a sense of accomplishment over Gaddafi.

Lothy:

And that means that America is left to take the heat every time because they ‘police the world’, even though their policing in a situation like this is far better than dead civilians in the streets.

Because we’re the so called ‘Leader of the free world’.

Mopman:

You seem to imply that “taking him out”, even if it wasn’t ridiculous, wouldn’t cause death in the streets.

Are you saying since the special unit is American theyll go in there guns blazin and shoot everyone and report back that Gaddafi is probably dead?

How is it ridiculous? If we remove him from office he’ll probably kill himself like Mubarak said he wanted to.

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

These sort of situations are a political nightmare for everyone involved.
The difference between countries like America and everyone else (Britain, Australia, New Zealand) is that America is prepared to act unilaterally.

Australia could send in a team that is just as capable as the Navy SEALs – we have an SAS regiment who are just as highly trained. So does Britain, New Zealand and numerous European countries, so there’s no shortage of special forces units in the Western world that could go in and put this dictator down overnight.
The difference is that no Australian politicians have the balls to make such a move.

And that means that America is left to take the heat every time because they ‘police the world’, even though their policing in a situation like this is far better than dead civilians in the streets.

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“goatee, post:17, topic:384488”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=480254.msg3516036#msg3516036 date=1299009109]
So what are you saying the US should do?
[/quote]

Condemn it verbally, but take no action until whatever is going on in Libya directly affects the safety of the American people or the USAs important allies. In otherwords, defend do not police.[/quote]

Hasn’t that already been done?

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

There could be hundreds of mercenaries though, that’s the problem.
With one known adversary, US intelligence can provide the team with pictures of him, his location, and call it a day.

Read full topic

item.title: The protests in Libya
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:15, topic:384488”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=480254.msg3515976#msg3515976 date=1299001934]
Pretty sure that the USA has already called for Khadaffi to step down, and condemned him for hurting civilians.
[/quote]

I’m not talking about just the US this time. The whole Western world has benefited from these dictators (not only Khadaffi). Khadaffi owns a big oil company in the Netherlands, and Royal Dutch Shell is, as the name suggests, partially Dutch. Shell is a big oil company in Libya, Nigeria (a different story, but same principal) and pretty much everywhere else.

What I’m saying is that we Westerners look the other way when that means that we get cheaper oil/other resources. Western leaders condemning this violence means bat shit, they should’ve stopped importing from those countries 30 years ago. These regimes exist because of their export.[/quote]

Maybe the people of the countries should have revolted 30 years ago?

edit:
Just heard Khadaffi said that thousands of his own people will die if UN or US forces attempt to enforce a no fly zone. Seems like a good enough reason to me to do it and help the people. Hopefully someone kills that nut.

Read full topic

Khadaffi owns a big oil company in the Netherlands, and Royal Dutch Shell is, as the name suggests, partially Dutch. Shell is a big oil company in Libya, Nigeria (a different story, but same principal) and pretty much everywhere else.

What I’m saying is that we Westerners look the other way when that means that we get cheaper oil/other resources. Western leaders condemning this violence means bat shit, they should’ve stopped importing from those countries 30 years ago. These regimes exist because of their export.
